|--------|----------|---------------|

| Tech | One stack | Flexible |
| Complexity | Lower | Higher |

slides.title: Benefits
slides.content:
# Microservices Benefits âœ…

## Independent Deployment:
- Deploy services separately
- Reduce deployment risk
- Faster release cycles

## Scalability:
- Scale only what's needed
- Cost-effective resources
- Handle varying loads

## Technology Freedom:
- Choose best tool for job
- Use different languages
- Different databases

## Team Autonomy:
- Small, focused teams
- Own their services
- Faster decision making

## Fault Isolation:
- One failure doesn't crash all
- Easier to debug
- Better resilience

slides.title: Quick Check
slides.quizQuestion: What is a key benefit of microservices?

slides.title: Challenges
slides.content:
# Microservices Challenges âš ï¸

## Distributed Complexity:
- Network failures
- Latency
- Data consistency

## Operational Overhead:
- More services to manage
- Monitoring complexity
- Deployment pipelines

## Data Management:
- Distributed transactions
- Data consistency
- No ACID across services

## Testing:
- Integration testing harder
- End-to-end testing complex
- Contract testing needed

## When NOT to Use:
- Small teams
- Simple applications
- Early-stage startups
- Limited DevOps maturity

slides.title: Decomposition Strategies
slides.content:
# Decomposition Strategies ğŸ”ª

## By Business Capability:
```
E-commerce Company:
â”œâ”€â”€ User Management

â”œâ”€â”€ Order Processing
â”œâ”€â”€ Payment Processing
â”œâ”€â”€ Shipping
â””â”€â”€ Notifications
```

## By Subdomain (DDD):
- Core Domain (competitive advantage)
- Supporting Domain (necessary)
- Generic Domain (common problems)

## Guidelines:
- High cohesion within service
- Low coupling between services
- Single responsibility
- Own data storage

## Signs of Wrong Boundaries:
- Frequent cross-service changes
- High network chatter
- Distributed transactions

slides.title: Service Size
slides.content:
# Service Size ğŸ“

How big should a microservice be?

## Guidelines:
- Small enough for one team
- Large enough to be meaningful
- "Can be rewritten in 2 weeks"
- Single business capability

## Too Small (Nano-services):
- Too many services
- Network overhead
- Operational nightmare

## Too Large:
- Hard to deploy
- Coupled components
- Scaling issues

## Right Size:
- 2-pizza team can own it
- Clear, focused purpose
- Independent deployment
- Own data store

slides.title: API Design
slides.content:
# API Design ğŸ“¡

## REST APIs:
```
GET    /users
GET    /users/{id}
POST   /users
PUT    /users/{id}
DELETE /users/{id}
```

## Versioning:
```
/api/v1/users
/api/v2/users
```

## Best Practices:
- Consistent naming
- Version your APIs
- Use HTTP properly
- Document with OpenAPI
- Return meaningful errors

## Error Responses:
```json
{
    "error": {
        "code": "USER_NOT_FOUND",
        "message": "User 123 not found"
    }
}
```

slides.title: When to Use
slides.content:
# When to Use Microservices ğŸ¤”

## Good Fit âœ…:
- Large, complex domains
- Need independent scaling
- Multiple teams
- Different tech needs
- High availability required

## Bad Fit âŒ:
- Small team (<10 people)
- Simple domain
- Rapid prototyping
- Limited DevOps skills
- Tight budgets

## Start Monolith?
- Many experts recommend
- Extract services later
- Learn domain first
- Easier to refactor

> "Don't even consider microservices unless you have a system that's too complex to manage as a monolith." - Martin Fowler

slides.content:

- Bounded contexts

### Trade-offs

|---------|----------|

| Flexibility | Operations |
| Independence | Consistency |
